item.question: You need to investigate which machine on your network fails to forward IP packets. Which command will be best to locate the machine?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
A user guru0 complains that he can not execute a script called makemeroot as shown above.
Which permission is needed to allow the user to execute the script?
item.hint: The question mentions that the command is a script. A script needs to be interpreted by another program. Therefore it is not the script itself that is executed. It only contains the command lines that must be executed.

item.question: Your senior system administrator asked you to edit the <font face="monospace">/etc/inetd.conf</font> file in order to disable the time service. After doing so, what would be the next thing to do?
item.choice: Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and send it a <font face="monospace">SIGHUP</font>.
Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and kill it with <font face="monospace">kill -15</font>.
item.correct_answer: Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and send it a <font face="monospace">SIGHUP</font>.
item.hint: Many daemons interpret the hangup signal as restarting and/or reloading the configuration file.

item.question: Based on what the above exhibit shows, which of the following statements is TRUE?
item.choice: The script will run daily to calculate the network routes.
The <font face="monospace">renice</font>-command will renice the previous command <font face="monospace">echo</font>.
The command <font face="monospace">calculateroutes</font> will be executed with the nice value <font face="monospace">19</font>.
The script will print the message “Starting route-calculation on” followed by the current date and time.
item.correct_answer: The command <font face="monospace">calculateroutes</font> will be executed with the nice value <font face="monospace">19</font>.
The script will print the message “Starting route-calculation on” followed by the current date and time.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following services are usually NOT protected via TCP wrappers?
item.hint: Some programs have builtin support for TCP wrappers, others are protected as they are started by <font face="monospace">inetd</font> or <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>. Some don't use TCP wrappers at all and have their own methods for access control. The Apache webserver is never started by <font face="monospace">inetd</font> or <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>.

item.question: Select the line that best represents the permissions for the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>.
item.hint: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> is used by many programs to locate the homedirectory of a user or get the username associated with a user ID. If permissions were to be too strict a lot of user friendliness would be disabled. For instance tilde substitution by the shell.

item.question: You execute the command <font face="monospace">date +%M</font>. What will the output show you?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which option can you use to select a different UID instead of the default when using the command useradd?
Select all correct answers
item.hint: This one is nasty. The question asks you to select all correct answers. However, this does not mean there must be more than one correct answer.

item.question: You get a complaint that domainname <font face="monospace">www.atcomputing.nl</font> cannot be reached. Which tool would be best to check if a router is causing problems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following fields are required in the <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> file for a user account? (Choose all that apply)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want to copy all files in the current directory to the directory <font face="monospace">/tmp/guru</font>. Which of the following scripts will copy all regular files without generating any file-permission errors knowing that you have write permissions for <font face="monospace">/tmp/guru</font>?
item.hint: We went a little overboard on this question and provided many choices with subtle differences. Read all choices very carefully and pay good attention to the if-statements.

item.question:
What syslog facility represents user authentication processes?
(Select all correct answers)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which two daemons will start services on demand?
item.hint: This question is about the concept of a super daemon. This is a daemon that will listen to network connections on behalf of other daemons. Whenever a connection is made the corresponding daemon is started by the super daemon to handle the network session. The benefit is that you only need one daemon running at all times and the super daemon can connect standard input and output to the network. The latter allows you to write a simple shell script as a network daemon.

item.question: What will DNS enable you to do?
item.hint: You might find that DNS is an essential part of the internet, and that without it, the internet just won't work for most people. However, internet stands for internetworking which stands for the practice of connecting a computer network with other networks through the use of gateways that provide a common method of routing information packets between the networks. Hence, DNS may use an internet to provide its services but techically does not manage or provide access to the internet.

item.question: What best describes “accessibility”?
item.choice: Accessibility is the degree to which a device is available to as many people as possible.
Accessibility is about making a device more easy to use.
Accessibility provides means to login on a computer system.
Accessibility is used to determine what you may or may not do on a computer system.
item.correct_answer: Accessibility is the degree to which a device is available to as many people as possible.
item.hint: Do not confuse accessibility with usability.

item.question: Which of the following lines from <font face="monospace">/etc/X11/xorg.conf</font> indicates a font server must be used?
item.hint: A font server is accessed through a communication service such as an IP network or Unix domain sockets. When you access a font server through a domain socket you need to specify <font face="monospace">unix</font> with the correct port number.

item.question: The above exhibit for contains a line from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>. Which of the following statements is true, based on the information in the exhibit?
item.choice: User <font face="monospace">guru1</font> belongs to the group with GID 5102.
The username <font face="monospace">guru1</font> belongs to the group <font face="monospace">GURU 1</font>.
Members of the group with GID 5001 can read directory <font face="monospace">/home/guru1</font>.
The file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> is corrupt as you may not use space-characters in a passwd-entry.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You just migrated your DNS server to a new machine and now need to update the clients to use the new DNS server. Which file do you need to change?
item.hint: The C library many programs use contains routines that provide access to DNS. This set of routines is called the resolver.

item.question: Which of the following tools is used to configure CUPS?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You edited the file <font face="monospace">/etc/resolv.conf</font> to point to the DNS server in your network. Unfortunately, the system does not use the configured DNS server to look up host names. What is most likely the problem?
item.choice: The localhost hostname is not properly configured in <font face="monospace">/etc/hosts</font>.
You do not have a <font face="monospace">/etc/named.conf</font> file.
The named daemon is not running on your computer.
The hosts entry in your <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font> does not list <font face="monospace">dns</font>.
item.correct_answer: The hosts entry in your <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font> does not list <font face="monospace">dns</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following lines would you find in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font>?
item.hint: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font> is used by the resolver library to check what and in what order it should consult to resolve a hostname to an IP address. Usually this is first the <font face="monospace">/etc/hosts</font> and second a remote DNS server.

item.question: Considering a Debian linux system. What are the default permissions for the <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> file?
item.hint: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> should only be readable and writable by the root user. However, on Debian systems the group <font face="monospace">shadow</font> is used to allow certain programs to read the file <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> as well.

item.question: How would you temporarily disable a user's login account?
item.choice: By changing the user's password and changing it back when the account needs to be enabled again.
By setting the user's shell to <font face="monospace">/usr/sbin/nologin</font> and changing it back to the default shell when the account needs to be enabled again.
Removing the user's entry in <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>.
Deleting the user account and recreate it afterwards.
item.correct_answer: By changing the user's password and changing it back when the account needs to be enabled again.
item.hint: Locking a user's account can be accomplished using the command <font face="monospace">passwd</font> with the option <font face="monospace">-l</font>. The way it locks an account is by simplying putting a <font face="monospace">!</font> or <font face="monospace">*</font> in front of the hashed password string in <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font>. This will result in an invalid hash for which no password will ever match. This effectively locks out a user from the system. Note that, if the user is currently logged in he or she will not be affected as long as he or she does not logout.

item.question:
Which of the following would execute the script updaterepository twice per hour between 20:00 and 06:00 hours
on monday to friday?
item.hint: The format for a system crontab entry is: minutes, hours, day of month, month, day of week, user, command.

item.question: Which configuration file would you edit to change the default options for ssh sessions to other machines?
item.hint: When a command name ends at the letter <font face="monospace">d</font> it usually refers to daemon. Therefore, <font face="monospace">sshd</font> refers to the daemon of the ssh service. The client program has the same name but without the <font face="monospace">d</font> at the end.

item.question: A user calls claiming that the network does not work. You remember adding an extra network-card to her machine yesterday and did not test the new setup. You have a feeling that the network cards might be conflicting. Which file would you check?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which crontab entry is best used to set the system time at regular intervals?
item.hint: In this case the time specification in the crontab entries does not matter. There is only one choice with a correct command that will set the system time.

item.question: You notice that a lot of users complain that reading manpages is very inconvenient and ask you if you can change the pager to use the command <font face="monospace">less</font> instead of <font face="monospace">more</font>. Which of the following files would you edit to make this change.
item.hint: The default pager can be set through the <font face="monospace">PAGER</font> variable. Therefore, you will need to find a way to set the <font face="monospace">PAGER</font> variable each time a user logs in and starts a shell. Also note that the skel directory is only effective for new users. The question is about changing the pager for current users as well.

item.question: The _________ command is used to modify or set the password expiration for a user.
item.hint: There are multiple commands that allow you to set or modify the expiration date for an account. Any of these commands is a correct answer.

item.question: You want to run <font face="monospace">logrotate</font> on a daily basis. What should you do to make this possible?
item.choice: Add or edit a configuration in <font face="monospace">/etc/logrotate.d</font>
Use the <font face="monospace">at</font> command to run <font face="monospace">logrotate</font> at a specific time
item.hint: Linux tries to keep to the principal small is beautiful. This is a design principle where each program does one thing and does it well. Therefore, logrotate will do only log rotation and there is a separate daemon to execute programs periodically.

item.question: In which file can you specify default xterm geometry settings for a specific user?
item.hint: The X Display Manager uses multiple configuration files that start with a capital <font face="monospace">X</font>.

item.question: What is the correct order in which the BASH shell will search for a command?
item.hint: When you provide a pathname, i.e. the commandname contains a forward slash, you tell the shell exactly where to find the command. Therefore it does not have to search for it in this case. When you only provide the commandname (i.e. without a forward slash) the shell will search for a command with the given name. This can be either a builtin (shell function) or an executable on a filesystem.

item.question: To synchronize the hardware clock with the system clock which command would you use?
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">date</font> will only set the system clock. The system clock is maintained by the kernel and may be out of sync with the hardware clock. Most Linux distributions will set the system clock equal to the hardware clock during system boot and vice versa during a shutdown.

item.question: Which of the following websites provide linux related news?
item.hint: You either know 'em or you don't. If you don't better check them out regularly to keep up to date.

item.question: Which of the following BEST describes what the <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> directory is used for?
item.choice: When the system boots the contents of the <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> directory is read and depending on the runlevel the scripts are executed.
Each time a user logs in the contents of <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> is used to initialize the shell environment.
The contents of the directory can be used to provide a default environment when new users are created.
It contains the configuration files for the application <font face="monospace">skel</font>.
item.correct_answer: The contents of the directory can be used to provide a default environment when new users are created.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You need to change a user's login name from <font face="monospace">sara</font> to <font face="monospace">sarah</font>. Which of the following commands would move her homedirectory to <font face="monospace">/home/sarah</font>?
item.hint: By default <font face="monospace">usermod</font> will use the login name as directory name for the home directory. Therefore, you will need to override the default behaviour. Also note that if an option requires an argument it must come directly after the option.

item.question: Which of the following IP networks does RFC 1918 reserve for use on private intranets?
item.hint: There are three such ranges. One is <font face="monospace">192.168.0.0/24</font> and another is <font face="monospace">172.16.0.0/12</font>. The third range is contains one of the ip adresses in the given choices.

item.question: You just installed a non-multiboot Linux system. What is the recommended time for the hardware clock?
item.choice: There is no recommendation concerning the hardware clock.
item.hint: On a computer system that needs to keep accurate time you will always encounter a Real Time Clock also known as the hardware clock. The Linux kernel however will not use the real time clock directly but will maintain a so called system clock. This system clock is set to UTC. During system startup the system clock is synchronized with the hardware clock and vice versa during the shutdown procedure. If the hardware clock is not in UTC, the kernel will convert the real time to UTC to be used in the system clock.

item.question: You discovered a pending job for the <font face="monospace">at</font>-command. Which of the following do you have to use to remove it?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The user bob complains that he cannot access his email. In which directory would you look to see if there is any delivered email for him?
item.hint: The default location for queues is under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>. In computer science, spool refers to the process of placing data in a temporary working area for another program to process. Each system that requires a spool creates its own directory under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>, usually named after the system that uses it.

item.question: The ______ command is used to print out the current date and time on the system.
item.hint: The question does not state if you should print the hardware or system time. Therefore, you may assume both are correct.

item.question:
Which of the following are desktop managers?
Choose all correct answers.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What file is used to display messages at the login prompt when users log in remotely using <font face="monospace">telnet</font>?
item.hint: As good sysadmin you probably disabled <font face="monospace">telnet</font> on all your systems and will never have use for the asked file. However, you do probably know the local version that is used to display a text message before the login prompt on a console login screen. This file also has a network version that is used when a login screen is presented over a network, for instance when using <font face="monospace">telnet</font>.

item.question: In order to bypass print filters using lpr, which of following switches should be used:
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which file is used by TCP Wrapper to determine which connections should be denied for a network service? (Provide the full path)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
What best describes the above output?
item.choice: The program <font face="monospace">xeyes</font> failed to execute.
item.hint: Every program that stops will return a so called exit code. This code tells the system if an error occured or not. The shell will keep the error code of the last command executed in the variable <font face="monospace">?</font>.

item.question:
The content of the file ~/myscript.sh is given in above exhibit.
What will be the output when you execute the following commandline?
~/myscript.sh i like penguins
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">shift</font> will shift all parameters one place to the left. Hence, <font face="monospace">$1</font> becomes <font face="monospace">$0</font>, <font face="monospace">$2</font> becomes <font face="monospace">$1</font>, etc. etc.

item.question: Which three services are mapped to the TCP/IP ports 80, 53 and 22 (in the listed order)?
item.hint: As you are required to pick the answer that has all three in the correct order you may be able to answer this one correctly even if you do not know all portnumbers.

item.question: An employee's contract has been extended from its original 6 months to 1 year. You originally set his account to expire after 6 months. You now need to extend this for an extra year. Which of the following commands would allow you to do this?
item.hint: Most programs try to make the options as much self explaining as possible. With one letter options this usually means that it is the first letter of the spelled out option name.

item.question: You want the command <font face="monospace">atc2</font> only to be executed when the command <font face="monospace">atc1</font> fails. Which of the following command lines will allow this?
item.hint: <font face="monospace">&&</font> stands for AND. <font face="monospace">||</font> stands for OR. These are evaluated from left to right using lazy evaluation. This means that if evaluating the next condition does not matter for the overall result, the next condition or conditions will not be evaluated. If you use a logical OR the overall result will be true if at least one of the conditions is true. If you use a logical AND all conditions must be true to make the overall result become true. Therefore, if you use a logical OR and the left command fails the next command will be executed. If the left command succeeds there is no need to execute the next command. When using a logical AND the next command will only be executed if the left command succeeded.

item.question: What best describes above statement?
item.choice: It will give an error as you can only select from one table at a time.

SELECT will delete all rows in the tables books and authors where
the id column in books matches the book_id column.
It will return only the columns <font face="monospace">title</font> and <font face="monospace">name</font> in the result.

It will select usage of the title and name on tables books and authors if and
only if the id equals book_id.
item.correct_answer: It will return only the columns <font face="monospace">title</font> and <font face="monospace">name</font> in the result.
item.hint: The statement comes from SQL. The SELECT will return rows FROM one or more tables using WHERE as a criterium.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. What does the number <font face="monospace">20738</font> represent?
item.choice: the process ID of the last command executed in the background
the process ID of the echo command
the process ID of the last command executed in the foreground
the process ID of the current shell
item.correct_answer: the process ID of the current shell
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the file <font face="monospace">/etc/host.conf</font> used for?
item.choice: To hold the hostname of the machine
To hold ip-address and hostname translations
To specify which other hosts are allowed to connect to this machine
item.hint: Not many sysadmins know of this file but it does exist. Although you will never need to edit this file we thought it might be nice to include some of the peculiarities of the Linux system as well. Its purpose was to configure the resolver library implemented in libc. It was used by an older version of libc (before glibc version 2) and it seems that it is not used anymore. However, glibc still reads the file but does not do anything with the contents. It has been superseded by the file <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font>.

item.question: Consider above exhibit. Which of the following statements if true?
item.choice: The column <font face="monospace">books</font> will be updated and set equal to <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
The table <font face="monospace">books</font> will be updated where <font face="monospace">title</font> equals <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
The table <font face="monospace">title</font> will be updated and all rows in the column <font face="monospace">books</font> will be set to <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
All rows will be updated in the table <font face="monospace">books</font>.
item.correct_answer: All rows will be updated in the table <font face="monospace">books</font>.
item.hint: The statement comes from SQL. The UPDATE will modify the cells for each rows in the column specified by SET.

item.question: which of the following statements is true considering the above exhibit that contains a part of <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>'s configuration?
item.choice: The agenda service must be included in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/services</font>
item.correct_answer: The agenda service must be included in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/services</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following are true? (Select all correct answers)
item.choice: Port 53 is used by the telnet service.
Port 143 is used by mail user agents to retrieve new mail.
Port 465 is used to provide encrypted HTTP traffic.
Port 25 is used by mail transfer agents to transport mail messages.
item.correct_answer: Port 143 is used by mail user agents to retrieve new mail.
Port 465 is used to provide encrypted HTTP traffic.
item.hint: LPI requires that you know the most common TCP and UDP ports. You can expect questions about portnumbers 20, 21, 22, 23, 25, 53, 80, 110, 119, 139, 143, 161, 443, 465, 993, 995.

item.question: Using <font face="monospace">xdm</font> users may create and edit a configuration file in their home directory that can tell the X window system what window manager they wish to start when they log in. Which file is that?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following protocols uses different network ports for data control and data transfer?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want to do a routine checkup on your system to see if anyone is trying to hack your way into the system. Which of the following commandlines would you use to check how many times remote users have opened a secure shell to the system?
item.hint: As authentication information is considered sensitive, most Linux distributions will log authentication information in a separate log file. This allows the system to restrict access to a specific user or group.

item.question: You are running an IPv6 network and a system on that network needs to sent a packet to another IPv4 only system with IPv4 address <font face="monospace">80.113.6.236</font>. Provide the IPv4 mapped IPv6 address.
item.hint: There are many ways to provide the asked address. However, you should provide the answer with the minimal amount of characters possible. Hence, reduce as much zero's as possible by <font face="monospace">::</font>.
